steps.speaker: Narrator
steps.text: It's been several months since the breakup. You’ve finally decided to start dating again. Your child is adjusting well, but the thought of introducing someone new still feels complicated.

steps.speaker: Inner Voice
steps.text: Do I even tell my ex I’m seeing someone?

choices.text: Yes, it’s better to be transparent.
No, it’s my private life for now.
Maybe after a few dates, if it becomes serious.

steps.speaker: Ex-Partner
steps.text: You seem happier lately. Is there someone new?

choices.text: Yes, I’ve started seeing someone. I wanted to be upfront about it.
That’s not something I want to discuss right now.
Kind of. It’s still early, nothing serious.

steps.speaker: Child
steps.text: Who’s that person you were talking to on the phone?

choices.text: That’s a new friend. You’ll meet them someday.
Don’t worry about it, it’s adult stuff.
Someone I care about, but I’ll always be your parent first.

steps.speaker: Ex-Partner
steps.text: I just hope whoever this is won’t confuse our child.

choices.text: I understand your concern. I’ll make sure introductions happen gradually.
You don’t get to control my personal life.
Let’s talk to the counselor about timing together.

steps.speaker: Narrator
steps.text: Weeks later, everyone seems calmer. The child understands that love can take many forms, and both parents are learning to respect boundaries.

choices.text: End on a cooperative note — you and your ex share a smile at drop-off.
Keep distance — peaceful but emotionally neutral.
Still rocky — your ex refuses to engage.

end.title: Moving On
end.text: No matter which path you chose, you’ve started building a more stable environment where your child feels secure and you regain emotional independence.
